1. Freetown
Shakespeare drops the word into Romeo and

21.text:
Juliet. When the Prince intervenes to quell
the riot between the Montagues and Capulets

26.text:
in the first scene, he concludes his speech
as follows:

30.text:
You, Capulet, shall go along with me,
And Montague, come you this afternoon,

36.text:
To know our farther pleasure in this case,
To old Freetown, our common judgement-place.

45.text:
Freetown!
Shakespeare got it from Brooke, where Capuletís

48.text:
castle is called Freetown; Brooke Englished
it from Painter, where Capuletís place is

55.text:
Villafranca. But, by transferring ëFreetowní
to the Prince, transposing it beyond the storyís

62.text:
scene, and making it ëour common judgement-placeí,
Shakespeare endued it with an authority which

68.text:
is suggestively otherworldly and egalitarian.
By making it ëold Freetowní he lent it a

75.text:
further, immemorial quality, as if it were
somehow always there, somehow positively shadowing

81.text:
the imperfections of our civic life. There
is a breath of equality in the Prince saying,

86.text:
ëYou, Capulet, shall go along with meí.
And the use of the word ëpleasureí in conjunction

92.text:
with Freetown anticipates something of the
sex and mutuality of Romeo and Juliet as opposed

98.text:
to the violence the Prince interrupts. But
Freetown is not a fantasy land of libertarian

104.text:
license. It is FreeTOWN, placeholder for a
real civil society: FREEtown, one that is

113.text:
defined above all by liberty and freedom.
And it also is ëour common judgement placeí,

121.text:
whose freedom is sourced in and guaranteed
by totally inclusive conversation and agreement.

131.text:
In this small but significant moment of literary
history, then, Shakespeare turned Freetown

136.text:
from the mere, meaningless name of a posh
villa into a real place and prospect, grounds

142.text:
for hope, albeit ones that remain just off
stage. Verona may be fair (ëIn fair Verona,

150.text:
where we lay our sceneí(Chorus, 2)) but Freetown
is fairer, and this activates a significant

156.text:
pun where Freetown is fairer because it is
fairer: more just.

164.text:
Freetown! It flashes on the mindís eye, and
then it is gone: ëlike the lightning which

170.text:
doth cease to be / Ere one can say ìit lightensîí
(2.2.119-20). But, for me at least, it appears

176.text:
in another fleeting epiphany in Romeo and
Juliet. Capulet has somehow tasked an illiterate

182.text:
servant with inviting a list of people over
to his momentous masked ball, where of course

187.text:
Romeo and Juliet will meet. When this nonplussed
man asks for help with reading the relevant

199.text:
Signor Martino and his wife and daughters;
County Anselm and his beauteous sisters;

206.text:
The lady widow of Vitruvio;
Signor Placentio and his lovely nieces;

213.text:
Mercutio and his brother Valentine;
Mine uncle Capulet, his wife and daughters;

220.text:
My fair niece Rosaline, and Livia;
Signor Valentio and his cousin Tybalt;

230.text:
Now Iím interested in the way that Mercutio
and Tybalt appear in this list. Later in the

235.text:
play Tybalt sneers, ëMercutio, thou consortest
with Romeoí, to which Mercutio snorts, ëìConsortî?

244.text:
What, dost thou make us minstrels?í (3.1.44-5).
The implication seems to be that Mercutio

251.text:
is gay, though if he is, heís unfulfilledóit
being something of a downer to be a gay man

257.text:
in love with the most famous heterosexual
in history. But then the list for Capuletís

262.text:
party actually intimates that Tybaltís gay
as well. Itís in verse, with each line economically,

267.text:
deftly, rather emblematically placing those
to whom Capulet is extending his invitation.

274.text:
Some are presented in terms of the patriarchal
familyóSignior Martino and his wife and daughters;

280.text:
the lady widow of Utruvio (a rather nice line
of blank verse); Mine Uncle Capulet, his wife

286.text:
and daughters. Other lines pair men with attractive
women: County Anselm and his beauteous sisters,

293.text:
Lucio and the lively Helena. And I feel compelled
to say that Signor Placentio with his trophy

299.text:
nieces sounds particularly disagreeably pleased
with himself. Anyway, it is in this overwhelming

305.text:
context of patriarchal families and lovely
girls that Mercutio and Tybalt are accompanied

310.text:
by male valentinesówhich in this the greatest
and most famous drama of sexual love in Western

316.text:
culture is highly suggestive to say the least.
The continuing conversation between Romeo

321.text:
and Capuletís unlettered retainer infuses
this prospect of sexual liberty with a transcendent,

328.text:
ROMEO A fair assembly. Whither should they
come?

335.text:
SERVINGMAN Up.
ROMEO Whither? To supper?

338.text:
SERVINGMAN To our house.
ROMEO Whose house?

345.text:
Of course the richest, most vivid icon of
freedom in Romeo and Juliet is the superbly

350.text:
realised, transgressive conjunction of Romeo
and Juliet themselves, but this exchange between

355.text:
Romeo and Capuletís unlettered servant fleetingly
extends the privileges of their love. ëA

362.text:
fair assemblyí: the pun on ëfairíójust
as well as beautifuló comes together with

367.text:
the political connotations of ëassemblyí
and ëhouseí to suggest that this heavenly

371.text:
fantasy could really be achieved by something
resembling democratic struggle. After all,

377.text:
the pleasures proferred by the Capulet ball
are very much this-worldly ones: good company,

381.text:
good food, romance, the possibility of sex.
That the benighted Capulet of Shakespeareís

387.text:
play is momentarily invested with a more celestial
authority sustains the possibility that sexual

394.text:
freedom might actually be realised here.
But then of course brother Valentine and Signor

402.text:
Valentio donít actually ëconsortí with
Mercutio and Tybalt at the Capulet ball; the

407.text:
play doesnít indicate that they make it to
the party at all. And yet, Capuletís bash

412.text:
as much as any other scene in the play dramatises
the political possibility of Freetown. This

417.text:
is because it is masked. Given identities,
privileges, prejudices and names are suspended,

424.text:
and the dialogue hints that the disguises
worn are actually truer to the undetermined

429.text:
potential of human freedom than the socially
recognisable, limited and corrupted faces

434.text:
they cover. It is this which enables Romeo
and Juliet to meet, converse, dance and fall

441.text:
in love. The ball truly is a fair assembly;
and to that extent, can be thought of as really

447.text:
taking place in Freetown, not Verona.
But the fair assembly could be fairer still.

455.text:
Romeo and Juliet condemns Mercutio to wild,
hilarious and melancholy opposition to a world

462.text:
which canít accommodate him. In Tybalt, Mercutioís
surreal irony becomes sheer fury. The male

470.text:
Valentines which Shakespeare so briefly conjures
for them express the tantalising possibility

475.text:
that Mercutioís and Tybaltís amazing energy
could be redeemed into a love which expresses

480.text:
the same degree of force in more positive
form. Romeo and Juliet lose their bliss in

486.text:
the process of attaining it: that is their
tragedy. But at least Romeo and Juliet attain

492.text:
their tragedy. We pity them but they make
it that far. Mercutio and Tybalt stand for

502.text: Itís time Mercutio and Tybalt got a dance.

506.text:
Brother Valentine, Signor Valentio: boys,
you too shall go to the ball!

514.text:
Hereís something we can do for Shakespeare
and Romeo and Juliet. We can imagine Mercutio

520.text:
and Brother Valentine, Signor Valentio and
Tybalt, masked or unmasked, wearing what you

526.text:
likeóor, better still, what they likeóand
dancing with four hundred years of emancipated

532.text:
joy. Of course Romeo and Juliet are there
too, their words, bodies and beings describing

537.text:
one shared smile, which this time isnít the
least bit star-crossed, misadventured or otherwise

543.text:
doomed. Thatís what a party in Freetown looks
like. Letís drink to it at the reception.

549.text:
*
OK, so far, so (I hope) uplifting: Freetown,

554.text:
the place with no bar to Romeo and Julietís
love, no bar to Mercutio and Valentineís!

560.text:
Bring it on. But weíre not finished yet.
Shakespeareís fearless exploration of free

564.text:
love suggests there is more to Freetown. The
balcony scene, for instance, takes us to the

569.text:
next level. Here are some of Julietís best
lines:

573.text:
My bounty is as boundless as the sea,
My love as deep: the more I give to thee,

579.text: The more I have, for both are infinite. (2.2.133-5)

584.text: Mmm, oceanic feeling phasing softly into endlessnessÖ.

590.text:
Iíve suggested the unfulfilled Mercutio relates
to the unredeemed world of Verona which canít

595.text:
positively accommodate him by means of energetic
irony, but of course such irony ultimately

600.text:
feeds off and so negatively preserves the
status quo. Julietís speech is actually more

607.text:
negative, going beyond all bounded forms of
life as we know it. Indeed, it is worth remarking

615.text:
that one of the most cherishable things about
Shakespeareís play is the way in which the

619.text:
utterly particularóa teenaged girlís amorous
enthusiasmóbecomes universal. But where does

626.text:
this leave us here below? Indeed, where does
it leave Juliet? It leaves her hungering for

631.text:
two things with a chance of accessing the
infinite: sex and marriage. Indeed, inasmuch

637.text:
as both aim at absolute union, these two are
one. But sex and marriage are forms of this

642.text:
life; they communicate with the infinite only
inasmuch as they become hospitable and even

647.text:
transparent to death. And this is where the
implied vision of Freetown and civic flourishing

652.text:
in Romeo and Juliet is radically, even frighteningly
changed. For it is clear that no simply positive

659.text:
adjustment, such as gay liberation, will enable
final fulfilment in Freetown. Identity politics

665.text:
isnít enough. Certainly the play asks us
to imagine how Mercutioís negativity might

670.text:
be more positively fulfilled by the negation
of negative conditions that gay liberation

675.text:
would entail. It insists Freetown has to be
able to accommodate Mercutio and Valentine

681.text:
as well as Romeo and Juliet. For Mercutio
and Valentine are entitled to their basic

688.text:
liberties, to sex and (why not?) marriage,
just as Romeo and Juliet require theirs. Nevertheless,

693.text:
it wonít do to imagine a smug and sated Mercutio;
it wouldnít even be Mercutio. Nor will it

699.text:
satisfy to imagine Romeo and Juliet in a better
world where they get married, have kids and

705.text:
get fat.
There is no Mercutio without his restless

710.text:
energy; no Romeo and Juliet without their
more positive negation of ordinary life for

715.text:
which another name is the infinite or eternal.
But wait: what form of social organisation

721.text:
could possibly accommodate this?! Julietís
ecstatic speeches turn explicitly away from

727.text:
light, just as Romeo was said to have done
in the first scene, favouring instead night,

733.text:
death and darkness. This is strange love grown
bold indeed, and its implications are more

739.text:
than personal in a play which doesnít indulgently
withdraw from the world but instead fearlessly

744.text:
explores the nature and destiny of free love
in relation to civic questions (3.2.15). Remember

750.text:
Juliet says, ëCome, civil nightí, and with
that the precious and enigmatic idea of Freetown

764.text:
2. Freeman!
In September 1769, the great Shakespearean

776.text:
actor David Garrick made Freetown a bit more
real; and he did so in the then obscure provincial

782.text:
English town that happens to be Shakespeareís
birthplaceóand of course now houses the Shakespeare

787.text:
Institute, not to mention the Shakespeare
Birthplace Trust, and the Royal Shakespeare

791.text:
Company. Garrickís Stratford Jubilee wasnít
just the first major Shakespeare celebration;

797.text:
it seeded all others. More than anything bar
Shakespeareís birth itself, it put Stratford

802.text:
on the map: indeed, for the first time it
provided decent access to the town by road.

808.text:
Whenever thereís cause to celebrate Shakespeare,
the Jubilee comes to mind, and itís no accident

813.text:
that the three authoritative book-length studies
were published in the previous anniversary

817.text:
year of 1964. Now that 2014 and the four-hundred-and-fiftieth
anniversary of Shakespeareís birth are upon

824.text:
usóand what with 2016ís four-hundredth anniversary
of Shakespeareís death fast approachingóthe

829.text:
Jubileeís interest freshens again. But itís
worth stressing that in 1769 it was all freshness.

837.text:
Cosy, ironic or weary familiarity with what
literary festivities have become can prevent

844.text:
us from grasping how novel and surprising
it was, perhaps even to Garrick himself. I

851.text:
suggest the Jubilee moved through Garrick.
It was a happening, mocked and marvelled at,

857.text:
ideologically disorganised, susceptible to
different interpretations; and yetóif only

862.text:
we have eyes to see itóinstrumental to the
association of Shakespeare with freedom that

867.text:
proved important to Western modernity and
might still provide us with a credible, substantial

873.text:
and interesting reason for celebrating Shakespeare
today.

878.text:
Stratford Town Council precipitated the Jubilee
by making Garrick its first ever Freeman,

884.text:
successfully flattering him into donating
a statue for the gaping niche in the Sheep-Street-facing

890.text:
facade of the recently rebuilt Town Hall.
But, practical considerations apart, transforming

896.text:
Garrick into the Freeman was a decisive step
towards the creative conjunction of Shakespeare

902.text:
and freedom. The actor had already done much
to link his name and fortunes with Shakespeareís,

907.text:
both on stage at Drury Lane, and by erecting
a ëShakespeare templeí in his garden at

913.text:
Hampton, whose fine statue by Roubiliac (now
in the British museum) was said to look as

925.text:
much like Garrick as it did the Bard. And
yet, Garrickís encroachment on the great

931.text:
manís identity and reputation was justified
inasmuch as he really did possess an actorís

936.text:
gift that was supremely well matched to Shakespeareís
talent for characterisation. With his darting

942.text:
glance and mobile face, he alone could live
up to the chameleon poet. Now Richard III,

955.text:
now Romeo, now Macbeth, he could seemingly
become anyone: Freeman indeed! Stratford formally

964.text:
honoured this freedom in an exquisite box
carved from the mulberry tree it maintained

969.text:
was ëundoubtedly planted by Shakespearís
own handí. This artefact, too, is now kept

976.text:
in the British Museum. It is a finely carved
piece, detailed with beguiling Shakespeareana,

982.text:
and a frieze on its back of Garrick as Lear
on the heath.

990.text:
In return for this rich gift of freedom, Garrick
furnished the Town Hall with its Shakespeare

995.text:
statueówhich (have a look next time youíre
there) still stands proud, if somewhat blackened

1000.text:
by age, over Sheep Streetóalong with a portrait
of Shakespeare to hang inside. Most importantly,

1006.text:
Stratfordís first Freeman gave the town its
Jubilee in honour of its most famous son.

1012.text:
And with that the idea of Freetown really
shimmers into life again.

1018.text:
Of course Garrick saw the Jubilee as a wonderful
opportunity to enhance his own interests,

1022.text:
celebrity and identification with Shakespeareóand
youíve got to say, why not? But it seems

1027.text:
equally clear he was moved to extend and share
the Shakespearean freedom which the Corporation

1033.text:
had conferred on him, and with which he no
doubt felt already blessed by the dramatist

1038.text:
in the form of his vocation for the Shakespearean
stage. With the Jubilee, Garrick took Shakespeare

1044.text:
to the people; he took him out of the institutions
of the theatre and scholarship and, quite

1049.text:
literally, to the streets.
This contemporary watercolour from the collection

1055.text:
of our friends at the Shakespeare Birthplace
Trust shows Garrick presiding over the Jubilee

1060.text:
in gorgeous style, sporting his long staff,
with his large mulberry-wood medallion hanging

1067.text:
round his neck, trimmed in multicoloured ribbon:
the Freeman as the rainbow man.

1074.text:
But Garrick wasnít just arrogating the Bardís
many-splendoured freedom to himself. On the

1079.text:
contrary: he really did give Shakespeareís
freedom away. To the schedule of the dayís

1084.text:
entertainments he added this: ëThe Steward
hopes that the Admirers of Shakespeare, will,

1089.text:
upon this Occasion, wear the Favors which
are called the Shakespeare Favorsí. Note

1095.text:
the Freeman is happy to turn Steward in order
to celebrate Shakespeareís freedom. The sashes,

1100.text:
rosettes, and badges he commends to the crowd
were made of a rich silk ribbon, three inches

1107.text:
wide, with a picot edge. The ribbon maker,
one Mr. Jackson of Coventry, explained in

1112.text:
the flyers that were handed about:
A Ribband has been made on purpose at Coventry

1117.text:
callíd The Shakespeare Ribband; it is in
imitation of the Rainbow, which, uniting the

1122.text:
Colours of all Parties, is likewise an emblem
of the great Variety of his Genius. ëEach

1129.text:
change of many colouríd Life he drewí.
Johnson.

1137.text:
Thus did every lapel in Stratford gorgeously
proclaim that Shakespeareís inclusive genius

1146.text: really was for each and all.

1151.text:
It was a constant theme of the Jubilee. Communal
feasting and singing were central. At the

1156.text:
most ceremonious banquet the Freeman served
up turtle: a hell of a turtle in factóit

1161.text:
weighed, when living, no less than 327 pounds.
Why turtle? ëLet the type and shadow of the

1169.text:
master grace his board,í Garrickís great
correspondent Edmund Burke had written, explaining

1174.text:
that it was the consummation of all meats,
and therefore most fitting for a dinner in

1179.text:
honour of one who ëcan represent all the
solidity of flesh, the volatility of fowl,

1185.text:
and the oddity of fishí. ëThe lad of all
lads was a Warwickshire lad,í sang Stratford,

1192.text:
and thus was Shakespeareís freedom at once
celebrated and brought home. And if the keynote

1198.text:
was of bright festivity, this wasnít exclusive
of more serious, even quasi-religious feelings,

1204.text:
as became clear when, after Garrick had edified
everyone with his Shakespeare Ode, they all

1209.text:
passed round and eagerly drank from a mulberry
goblet that was ornamented with silver. ëGarrick

1215.text:
was a worshipper himselfí, as Cowper wrote
in The Task:

1219.text:
He drew the liturgy, and formíd the rites
And solemn ceremonial of the day,

1225.text:
And callíd the world to worship on the banks
Of Avon, famíd in song.

1232.text:
He called the world to worship. ëIt is scarce
credible the Number of Persons of all Ranks

1237.text:
that came to see ití, marvelled The Public
Advertiser. The costs may have been prohibitive,

1243.text:
and Garrick may have ridiculed the Stratford
locals when he reprised the Jubilee for his

1247.text:
Drury Lane audiences, but the original intention
and atmosphere of his first ever Shakespeare

1252.text: Jubilee was unprecedentedly liberal and inviting.

1256.text:
And if it at least symbolically involved everyone,
it also extended a new spirit of tolerant

1261.text:
inclusiveness to all aspects of human personality.
ëWenches! never was any paradise so plentifully

1268.text:
and beautifully inhabited as here at this
timeí, according to the excited correspondent

1274.text:
of Lloyds Evening Post. And if you didnít
like wenches, there was a horse race.

1280.text:
Garrick didnít dodge the darker aspects of
freedom we have seen already in Romeo and

1284.text:
Juliet. His Bard is the more god-like for
his daemonic inscrutability. Consider lines

1291.text:
The subject passions round him wait;
Who thoí unchained, and raging there,

1296.text: He checks, inflames, or turns their mad career.

1301.text:
This presents Shakespeare as a sorcerer possessed
of a hectic and rather frightening power in

1306.text:
tension with the civilizing mission that the
Ode otherwise invests him with. And when Garrick

1311.text:
tries to phase away from such daemonic passions
into an overwhelming joy, that joy quickly

1317.text:
darkens into a wildly permissive sensuality
which seems to remember and reprise them.

1322.text:
ëWith kindling cheeks, and sparkling eyesÖ
the Bard in transport diesí (p. 9): this

1331.text:
makes us very intimate with Shakespeare indeed.
The Ode goes on to envision in intricate detail

1337.text:
his ecstatic mental impregnation, the huge
fruit of which is testimony, of course, to

1341.text:
his amazing fertility, but also suggests an
exceptionally painful birth. For what springs

1347.text:
fully formed from Shakespeareís head isnít
a paragon of conventional virtueónor even

1352.text:
some sylph-like goddess, nor even Hamletóbut
rather the enormous libertine Falstaff, his

1358.text:
superabundant largeness very explicitly expressing
a vitality that exceeds all limits. Or, as

1364.text:
Garrick, puts it: ëa world where all pleasures
aboundí For, weíre told, ëthe world too

1373.text:
So FALSTAFF will never decline,
Ö

1376.text:
And his rain and his rivers are wine;
Ö

1379.text: And away with all sorrow and care. (p. 10)

1383.text:
Thus the rainbow man presents the fat man
as the happy avatar of all the freedom and

1389.text:
fullness of Shakespearean being. And he does
so without blanding out the darker shades

1394.text:
of the spectrum such freedom entails. That
he does in public and in relation to rebuilding

1400.text:
a town hall and, by implication, a real community
is striking, and perhaps should put us on

1405.text:
our mettle as we celebrate Shakespeare in
14/16. At its heart, Garrickís civic Shakespeare

1412.text:
Ode offers an undiscriminating celebration
of life. Banish plump Jack, and banish all

1420.text:
the world; but Falstaff returns from banishment
to Stratford in 1769 to become the unexpected

1427.text:
type of civic flourishing, a flourishing based
not as it usually is on sacrifice and repression

1434.text: but on emancipating all we desire and are.

1439.text:
The first ever Shakespeare Jubilee has been
especially mocked for not, in fact, including

1443.text:
any Shakespeareóand it is difficult to imagine
that a Shakespeare festival today could get

1447.text:
away without including any plays or poems.
But Iíve been trying to bring out a neglected

1452.text:
radical stripe to what Garrick did. He celebrated
Shakespeare not so much as literary heritage

1457.text:
to be preserved against the depredations of
time and change, but instead as example and

1463.text:
inspiration. He celebrated Shakespeare as
the very quintessence of freedom, as the proof

1486.text:
The political muse of the Jubilee was the
maverick demagogue John Wilkes. Champion of

1491.text:
electoral reform, freedom of religion, freedom
of the press, and even a free America (more

1497.text:
of which later), Wilkes was the foremost figurehead
for liberty in British politics. But he was

1502.text:
just as much a libertine: author of the pornographic
poem, ëAn Essay on Womaní, and leading light

1508.text:
of the Hellfire Club, who dressed in Franciscan
robes to enact mad, drunken debauchery with

1514.text:
courtesans attired as nunsóand on one infamous
occasion, a baboon. The inspiring attractions

1521.text:
of political liberalism, and the darker freedoms
it might entail, come together in Wilkes.

1526.text:
When he was imprisoned for seditious libel
for his attack on George III in number 45

1531.text:
of his radical paper, The North Briton, the
cry of ëWilkes and Liberty!í rang through

1538.text:
British politics. The protest was serious
and sustained, with seven protestors dying

1543.text:
as they chanted, ëNo liberty, no Kingí at
the St Georgeís Field Massacre in 1768. Jubilees

1552.text:
in honour of Wilkes and liberty preceded Garrickís
first Shakespeare jubilee, and had provided

1558.text:
a model for it. Coverage of events in Stratford
in Lloydís Evening Post on the 8th of September

1564.text:
1769 made the connection, but Garrick also
alluded to it himself in a cryptic announcement

1570.text:
placed in the Public Advertiser of the 8th
of July, 1769:

1576.text:
A CARD
The Mulberry Box presents Compliments to the

1581.text:
Standish of the same Materials, hoping they
shall meet very soon at the London Tavern,

1586.text:
and that an uninterrupted Friendship may thenceforward
succeed to their late Separation, as they

1591.text:
are appointed to Joint Shares in the same
Office, viz. Grooms of the Stool to the Supporters

1600.text:
Well, I say cryptic but youíll recognise
the mulberry box as the exquisite artefact

1605.text:
weíve met already within which Garrick received
his Freedom of Stratford. The ëstandish of

1610.text:
the same materialsí was a gift given by the
town to George Keate for delivering his freedom

1616.text:
to Garrick. The Society of the Supporters
of the Bill of Rights was founded in 1769

1623.text:
to aid Wilkes and press for parliamentary
reform; it is the first major extra-parliamentary

1629.text:
political association in Britain. Garrick
therefore, in the Evening Post, is making

1634.text:
a connection between the Freedom of Stratford
and the serious campaign for political freedom

1639.text:
that is getting underway in this period; indeed,
he subordinates Shakespeare and Stratford

1644.text:
to that real-world campaign by casting himself
and Keate as ëGrooms of the Stool to the

1649.text: Supporters of the Bill of Rightsí.

1651.text:
But of course the political vitality of the
association of Shakespeare and freedom outlasts

1656.text:

4. Viva la Libert‡!
Michael Dobson has pointed to a major apparent

1923.text:

1928.text:

1934.text:

perhaps help resolve this tension. Shakespeareís

1939.text:
freedom frees the English to be themselves,
throwing off the yoke of more established

1944.text:
cultures: Greece, Rome and France. Free Shakespearean
England then, in turn, sets other cultures

1949.text:
free. This romance of freedom explains why
news of the first Shakespeare Jubilee was

1954.text:

despite Garrickís mocking subversion of French

1959.text:

1965.text:

1970.text:

works. Germany is the most striking example

1988.text:

to represent their own potential freedom to

1999.text:
the Jubilee itself. ëIt was not confined

2004.text:

2019.text:

2023.text:

2029.text:

But Garrick was probably also influenced by

2033.text:

2057.text:
Boswell came to Stratford resplendent in the

2065.text:
As the latter-day editors of his journals

2070.text:

2081.text:

2086.text:

He personally raised money to arm the rebels,

2091.text:

2096.text:

Account of Corsica; The Journal of a Tour

2102.text:

2108.text:

a real impact on European politics. The French

2114.text:

2118.text:
But, in spite of Boswellís efforts, they
werenít about to declare war on France on

2123.text:
behalf of a small island of apparently little

2128.text:

2132.text:

2138.text:

2144.text:

2167.text:

It suggests that the time was ripe for Garrick

2433.text:

range on a civilian crowd, at least twenty

2804.text:
But Shakespearean freedom had another major
effect on American politics, and in such a

2810.text:
way as still further darkens the motif. We
have seen that Wilkes was, via Garrick, associated

2816.text:
with Shakespeare as a proponent of freedom,
and he had a major impact on American revolutionary

2821.text:
thought. But in American history Wilkes and
Shakespeare are most strikingly reunited in

2827.text:
the career of John Wilkes Booth, who of course
assassinated Abraham Lincoln.

2837.text:
Booth was the son of the English Shakespearean
actor Junius Brutus Booth, who was Edmund

2843.text:
Keanís greatest rival. Junius Brutus was
named after the most obvious exemplar of Shakespearean

2849.text:
freedom, and the one who, at least in part,
inspired Booth to kill the President. Kean,

2856.text:
for his part, could be cast as an exemplar
of Shakespearean freedom at its most unrestrained,

2861.text:
and the assassinís alcoholic bigamist and
not infrequently deranged dad (aka ëThe Mad

2868.text:
Tragedianí) certainly gives him a run for
his money, but thatís another story. Booth

2873.text:
himself was named after that other avatar
of liberty we have met already: John Wilkes,

2878.text:
a distant relative. His family home, which
is still standing, was called Tudor Hall.

2884.text:
He went to the Miltonís Boarding School for
Boys. He became an actor and if he acted in

2889.text:
Julius Caesar (or excerpted scenes) just six
times, he nevertheless knew the play by heart

from childhood. He was a notable talent, Whitman

2902.text:
ëreal geniusí. In 1863 in Washington he

Boothís sister recalled that as the Confederacyís

started to fulminate in ëwild tirades against

2921.text:
E. Lee surrendered at Appomatox Court House,

2924.text:
the only play he wanted to be in now was Venice

in Boothís nature came together at once ñ

2967.text:

upon as a common cutthroat.í The best oí
thí cut-throats: as his final diary entries

3045.text:
a Shakespearean actor; namesake of that radical

3052.text:

3059.text:
Shakespearean freedom. Liberalism and its
